basics.name: Austin Tasato
basics.label: Student
basics.summary: I am studying for a B.S. in Computer Engineering at the University of Hawaii. I expect to graduate in Spring 2018.

work.summary: Joined the AWS Commerce Platform division's Fraud Prevention Team. Worked for 12 weeks with mentorship on an automation tool which involved heavy use of design patterns in Java, API use, and internal deployment practices (related tools/libraries: Mockito, JUnit, Eclipse IDE). Got experience with standard practices in unit/integration testing, continuous integration, code reviews, and light on-call issue resolution. Used various AWS services -- AWS Lambda, SNS, SQS, DynamoDB, CloudWatch, etc. Deployed majority of project to production. Touched lightly on Node.js and testing with Mocha.

Participated in the 2016 Summer Games internship program for 9 weeks after participating in the first WhatIf? ideas festival for Booz Allen Hamilton in Honolulu. Worked on a virtual reality project; primarily worked with sound effect synthesis and United State Geological Survey GIS data adaptation for 3D landsacpe modeling.

work.position: Machine Learning and Forecasting Team Member
work.summary: http://reishawaii-scel.org/ - REIS is the Renewable Energy and Island Sustainability Lab, and SCEL is the Smart Campus Energy Lab subdivision dedicated to improving the efficiency of the production of energy. Our primary work involves work on weather boxes and using weather information to improve the production of green energy. The machine learning and forecasting team is a fairly new team that experiments with methods for predicting weather information using modern methods and technologies. Our primary focus is towards Jupyter (formerly known as iPython) as a platform to perform regression and prediction on our data. We use statistical methods to analyze the data we receive from our in-house designed weather boxes.

work.company: The Research Corporation of the University of Hawai'i
work.summary: Joined and worked as an intern under Dr. Lana Garmire and the Cancer Epidemiology Program at the University of Hawaii Cancer Center. Current area of work involves implementing a workflow application for single-celled RNA-sequencing data using a web development framework with Shiny in the statistical programming language R. Gained exposure to statistical methods for normalization, outlier reduction, unsupervised/supervised clustering, differential expression analysis, and gene enrichment analysis using, e.g. Gene Ontology or the Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes. Used the Shiny web application framework for R extensively through the course of development.
